journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability

title-group.article-title: Analysis and quantification of systems – a formalized definition of reliability topologies and characteristic values for system quantification

article-meta.aff: 1TRW Automotive, Lucas Varity GmbH, Koblenz, Germany
2Chair of Dynamics and Control (SRS), University of Duisburg-Essen, Duisburg, Germany

author-notes.corresp: *TRW Automotive, Lucas Varity GmbH, Carl-Spaeter-Str. 8, 56070 Koblenz, Germany. email: marco.junglas@trw.com

abstract.p: The necessity for analysis, quantification, and optimization of mechatronic systems is growing in importance. Mechatronic systems combine methods and approaches from the mechanical, the electrical, and the information science domains. To make quantification of systems possible, the interfaces between these domains have to be described in a reusable manner. Especially during the development process, mechatronic systems need to be quantified with respect to their reliability characteristics. Decisions at an early design phase with respect to topology and hardware parameters regarding satisfying the requirements have to be quantified with respect to their reliability properties. The strongest requirements by law are focused on reliability and safety-oriented aspects of safety-relevant systems or components. This approach introduces a method supporting reliability evaluation from the early stage of design through to production. Here a new form of system structure description is introduced. This allows for the description of conflicts between several additional aspects such as cost and spatial needs, and possibly the consideration of alternatives. Based on the previously-mentioned description, parametrical and structural optimization can be realized, which will be the focus of forthcoming papers. This paper describes the necessary formal step from system specification to the formal system description. During the design stage, when relevant system factors are determined, the system architecture is designed and a function-oriented topology tree is generated. The development of a reliability-oriented topology, considering the reliability-oriented aspects, can be carried out.

In particular, costs, as important parameters for decisions about product design and production, can be integrated and considered. This approach deals with the formalized quantification of system reliability-related topology and related interdependencies with respect to the reliability characteristics. Therefore all domains of the mechatronic systems are considered.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: During the last years of automotive system development, the product life cycle in general [1], and therefore the product development time, has decreased. It has become necessary to maintain short development times to meet customer expectations concerning the quality, costs, and reliability of the product. The product cost summarizes the development costs, production costs, material costs, cost of risks, service costs, warranty costs, and cost of failures. The costs of failures are increasing during the product life cycle. The rule of ten describes the relations between failure costs and product life phase [2, 3]. Considering the overall product life of approximately 24 years in the automotive industry and the failure costs behaviour, it is very important to make decisions regarding system topology as early as possible. (Topology describes systems architecture/structure in different domains of mechatronic systems. A topology can be a combination of the information architecture (software), the mechanical structure, or the electrical schematic of a system. A functional structure can be used to describe the system’s overall behaviour. A formal form or block diagrams can be used to describe the topology.)

The resulting short design and development phases claim to realize parallel and supported development processes. To improve the development process and to prevent high failure costs, the process should be optimized. Additional to the decreasing development time, the complexity of technology increases in general: integration of functions get tighter and open architectures on networks of embedded systems are used. As a consequence, a conflict between the necessary functional complexity of the system and the development time arises. So, a new integrated form of system description may be helpful in realizing straightforward oriented development processes.

This approach proposes an easy-to-handle formalized system/structure description to be used for reliability and safety analysis support. The idea is to support all engineering domains from the beginning of the development to the end of the product life cycle management. Characteristic values for system quantification are also pointed out. System-level reliability and related modularity of the system is considered. The proposed top-down strategy allows a very early application within the process of system design. The prediction of system reliability and the analysis of system values are used at every stage of design to identify problems to meet the given system requirements and to correct occurring problems as early as possible. In this context the main goal of this contribution is the establishment of a transparent product quantification process with organized reusability of earlier quantified system parts. In conclusion the main goals are:

list-item.p: supporting the development of products from the early stage of design (innovation) to the series of products;
reliability quantification of systems, especially in system parts, in a reusable manner;
supporting the engineers in design or change decisions;
evaluation of system components regarding their sensitivity, importance, etc.;
realizing solution support via history data (construction set) for the engineers;
establishment of hints for optimization and defining weak points of the system;
realizing an interface to the optimization process [4].

sec.p: Here the focus is on mechatronic systems. In the next section an introduction to the structure of mechatronic systems is given. The currently-used methods for system description are listed. The difficulties of using these methods for involved teams are summarized. A system evaluation process was introduced to support the system quantification. For the system structure description a novel system matrix was defined. The information from the quantification of the considered systems variant is mapped into a knowledge base. This builds the base parts of the system construction set. Finally, the overall system decision and optimization process is shown.

sec.title: 2 Background, Motivation And State Of The Art
sec.p: The automotive industry is constrained by many requirements. In particular, the motivation to integrate more and more electronic components into cars may result in conflicts. Innovations show the possibility and tendency for the electrification of cars. The by-wire technologies become more and more a part of the focus of the original equipment manufacturer (OEM). By-wire systems use fewer mechanical parts and therefore need more fault-tolerant structures. These structures can be realized by redundant structures to fulfil safety and reliability requirements. Redundant structures are usually more expensive than mechanical fall-back solutions. This disadvantage can be outweighed by the higher functionality of the systems. Via implementation of by-wire structures, the mechanical parts are replaced by electromechanical units and processing units with wired connections. Former mechanical systems are redesigned into mechatronic systems.

Mechatronics is therefore an interdisciplinary field of engineering (Fig. 1). The aspect of safety engineering in the development of mechatronic systems is becoming more and more a focus. In this context the evaluation of system reliability is made, currently, for each domain separately and usually late in the development cycle. As a consequence the evaluation of the reliability of the whole system is also only possible very late. In particular, for the overall system reliability it is necessary to combine the quantification processes. To overcome the problem of different system descriptions, methodological developments in the domains of overall methods for all domains should be made. The possibility to describe the system behaviour for all domains and their interfaces with one unique procedure is thus a necessary methodological step. In the automotive industry system development is usually done using the V-model [5]. The V-model was stimulated by software development [6] and then further developed and applied to the mechatronic domains. In the beginning a summary of requirements (functional requirements, cost requirements, safety requirements, etc.) is made. Within the V-model procedure the system development starts with analysis of the system requirements followed by the definition of an initial system structure. The result, and final point, of the V-model is the release for production. The system design results in a domain-specific design, so the assurance of properties can be continuously checked. Considering these aspects, the later-introduced system evaluation process combines the domains and provides a base for the further quantification process.

In VDI 2206 [5] a methodology for the design of mechatronic systems is introduced. The evaluation procedure of mechatronic domains is usually described using the so-called V-Model [5]. The quantification of reliability and safety aspects is not described in detail. It is only mentioned that the methodology improves the reliability and safety of the product. In the case of automotive system development the focus is set on safety aspects. In IEC 61508 [7] the requirements of safety and reliability of electrical/electronic/programmable electronic safety-related systems were defined. In particular, the functional safety aspect is considered. This norm was the baseline for ISO 26262. For the automotive industry ISO 26262 [8] was designed and released as a baseline version. This standard defines the relevant steps for the evaluation of automotive systems. This standard considers the development of the system consisting of hardware and software parts. The development of these parts is also considered separately. The separated development process of the mechatronic domains also separates the consideration of the hardware and software for an overall quantifying process (considering the hardware as well the software parts). Additionally, an overall unique system structure description is necessary, and a description of the functional behaviour considering all system parts is essential.

Safety and reliability evaluations use failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) and fault tree analysis (FTA) methods for the analysis of systems. These methods are based on a detailed system structure description. The description can be generated by analysing the requirements. They are supported by functional descriptions describing the system and its behaviour. If an automated analysis of the system is to be realized, the structure has to be defined in a formal manner. For the description of the system structure suitable languages are developed. This group of languages is known as Architecture Description Language (ADL). The Unified Modeling Language (UML) [9] and the SYStem Modeling Language (SysML) [10], which is based on UML, are the most common languages describing architectures. The Architecture Analysis and Design Language (AADL) [11] was introduced by the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE). This description language is not as common as UML. To use these languages for automated system analysis, it is necessary to use an annotated model [12]. In most cases these models are specific and detailed in each domain. It is necessary to support all domains which are connected in the product life cycle by describing the system structure for the entire system.

A few approaches deal with the automated analysis of systems from models. The weak point results from the fact that often no model of a system exists, especially in an early system design phase. For the mechanical part of the system a time-consuming procedure results, in order to generate such models just in time during the development. That is the reason why usually this kind of system model in the automotive industry does not exist. Even if such models exist, they are defined in their specific domain so it would be necessary to integrate the domain-specific models into a whole-system model.

A model-based synthesis of fault trees from MATLAB simulink models was introduced by Papadopoulos in reference [13]. This approach is based on computer HAZOP (Hazard and Operability Studies) and considers mainly the software fault tree analysis. The models are aligned in a hierarchical structure and annotated for reliability quantification issues. In reference [14] the methodology of the hierarchical structure analysis is described in more detail. Another approach realizing automated fault tree generation out of models is described in reference [15], where the focus is mainly on software issues. A model-driven safety evaluation based on components with failure annotations is described in reference [16]. These approaches show the possibility of describing the system formally and to generate the system structure description automatically. To do this, an annotation of the model is necessary. On the other hand, the generated fault tree or the defined reliability models can be used for system structure description considering reliability issues. A usual problem in early development design phases is that only abstract functional models on a low detail level are available. Therefore these methods are not easily applicable at this early phase of the product life cycle.

Other approaches deal with the prediction of quality or reliability in early design phases [17, 18]. These approaches focus mostly on mechanical systems. Several approaches consider the reliability of software in detail [19, 20, 21, 22]. A discussion about the reliability analysis of software is not within the focus of this approach, so implicitly software is assumed as reliable. The reliability improvement of software is secured by the applied development process [6, 8]. In this contribution software faults are considered as systematic faults. This kind of fault is made in the specification or the incorrect implementation of the requirement within the embedded software. The objective is to combine hardware and software from a functional viewpoint. The system under consideration was treated as a modular system, which is built up of atomic units.

To summarize, there should be only one unique procedure for system description under consideration of the entire system. Additional system descriptions should be possible using graphical drawings. The DSM (Design Structure Matrix) approaches deal with the description of the system dependencies, the support of the development process, and the support of the product design. It is mainly used for the description of a system from a project point of view. The matrix was introduced and further developed in approaches from Lindemann [23] and Browning [24]. The DSM method is based on the approach introduced by Steward in reference [25]. This approach deals with the definition of the Design Structure System and describes the variables of the system used and their dependencies. The DSM describes the structure dependencies to describe and handle the product complexity. The DSM is an easy-to-use method to perform both the analysis and the management of complex systems. It enables the user to model, visualize, and analyse the dependencies between the entities of any system and derive suggestions for the improvement or synthesis of a system. The DSM describes the dependencies of the system components for the analysis mainly for administration purposes and does not support the evaluation of reliability quantification.

sec.title: 3 Analysis, Quantification, and Optimization
sec.p: This approach deals with the support of the development process from an early stage of design (innovation) to the series production release. For this, a rough architecture of the considered system has to be defined and then iteratively detailed during the development of the system. The automated reliability-oriented quantification of systems during the development phase depends on the splitting of the systems into functional subsystems. These generated subsystems are treated as atomic units. (Atomic units are subsystems which cannot be divided further into subsystems. These subsystems are defined to consider reliability aspects, they do not take into account physical dependencies.) The generated subsystems are quantified by applying reliability quantification methods. With these quantified modules a modular construction set is created and used for further development. This modular construction set is useful, because the system can be composed out of a pool of quantified subsystems. With this concept it is possible to change the system topology and search for alternative system designs.

With the objective of formalization of the decision process, reliability-oriented automation during the product life cycle becomes possible. The developed approach will provide essential information to the responsible developers during the whole development phase of the product. The influence and sensitivity factors give additional information with respect to the optimization potential of the system. This reliability-oriented approach includes hints for system topology optimization, leading to improved system reliability. The final step of the proposed new approach is to realize full integration of the analysis, quantification, and optimization into an automated global system evaluation loop. The mentioned contributions provide an evaluation of the system factors and system reliability during phases of development and design. The application of this approach makes both a smart system design decision during the system design phase and a comprehensive reliability-oriented feedback of the product development possible.

sec.title: 3.1 System evaluation process
sec.p: The proposed overall system evaluation process, as shown in Fig. 2, is divided into three parts. It starts with a system requirement analysis followed by the system architecture design. The system matrix generation resulting from the architecture or the requirements and from the evaluation of reliability respectively are assigned to the second step. The quantification of the system appears as the last step of this quantification process.

The first step considers the analysis of the system. Requirements (e.g. defined by the customer, company, law) and economic considerations affect the development of the system. The generation of system requirements is followed by the definition of the system architecture. The system architecture includes all information about the favourable system topology and should be made in a modular manner. The descriptions of the architecture are made for the mechanical hardware, electrical hardware, software, and internal structure of the considered system. In general, the system architecture design considers the tree domains separately. If the considered system for evaluation is only a part of the holistic system, additional information about the integration environment and architecture is necessary. This additional architecture description should describe the interfaces through the entire system and the overall system behaviour in which the developed system should work.

Based on this system description the system matrix is generated. The system matrix includes all information for the system reliability evaluation. The main challenge results from the evaluation of the software structure of the system. With the requirement of properly-working software, the programmable logic unit into which the software is integrated is the only component which could influence the software fault behaviour. Therefore the software reliability evaluation is not of interest; it is assumed that the software was designed and developed regarding the software development process. Here the focus is set on functional structures. In the case of mechatronic systems with programmable units the functions are implemented there. Considering software functions, virtual interdependencies between the system inputs are created. These dependencies are considered in the functional structures and turned into real dependencies, so the system matrix combines dependencies in the three mechatronic domains, as well as material flows, energy flows, and information flows. The matrix is used to define the reliability dependencies and considers additional structure of the system. It is also possible to value other qualities or economical factors, like safety or costs, of the product.
The system matrix supports the FMEA and FTA of the safety case evaluation. A detailed reliability-oriented structure description is necessary and is provided by the system matrix.

From this system matrix, the generation of system reliability topology and the calculation of the system reliability are performed. The introduced system matrix uses hardware and functional modules in relation to each other. Reliability evaluation appears as the last step of the process. The analysis of the system matrix and generation of optimizing proposal in a decision loop process appears as the core part of the proposed approach.

sec.title: 3.2 System description using the system matrix
sec.p: This section describes the development of the system matrix. For the evaluation of the system matrix it is necessary to identify and quantify the potential risks of each function to be realized using the FMEA [26] or the hazard analysis. After definition and selection of potential critical functions the requirement analysis has to be made. From this, the functional topology and the system matrix are evaluated. The generated system matrix is analysed and the system quantification values are valued. Within section 3.3.3, ‘Automatic system matrix development’, a short introduction to known automated system analysis methods of models is given. The related system analysis for cases of requirements is introduced. Additionally, for the case of available additional requirements, information on automated system matrix generation is given.

sec.title: 3.2.1 System description techniques
sec.p: For the requirement analysis the system is considered as a black box system. A black box is defined by the understanding of use of an input–processing–output chain. The system function is defined by the conditions of the system. Additionally, the disturbances have to be considered. The black box point of view is converted into a white box view. This is done by detailing the system description and specifying the system, so the system design will result in a functional system design. From this it is possible to generate a functional block diagram (Fig. 4).

In the case of automotive system development the system design starts typically with an abstract description using block diagrams. These diagrams are further developed and detailed in the following development steps. A function block diagram (FBD) describes the functional behaviour of the system, considers the hardware as well as the software components, and describes the interconnection between the system components. The common usage of FBD in the design representation process is the reason for choosing this form of system description.

Compared to a standard system view (Fig. 3), with input, processing, and output as main parts, the proposed general system view considers the mechatronic aspects in a more comfortable manner. The interfaces between the processing unit, the input unit(s), and the output unit(s) are shown in the FBD. Therefore FBDs are very comfortable for the illustration of complex systems. The signal processing units are used for the adaption of the inputs to the model core in the processing part and for the output in the processing part. The model core implements the internal functions of the system, which are often realized in software and can be divided into hierarchical aligned layers. Here the dependencies of the system components are given. The diagram combines the hardware and software component view. The FBD (signal flow graph) and the reliability model view are very similar. With the topology information of the system it is possible to detect the dependencies of the system components. In Fig. 4 this behaviour is shown in detail for an example system.

With the information about the sensors dependencies, it is possible to state the reliability block diagram and the fault tree template of the system. The fault tree of the example system shown in Fig. 4 is shown in Fig. 5. The implemented logic block is shown in the box. While it is integrated in a processing component, the logic block has no failure rate. Only the input ports are put in relation to each other. This dependency information is used for further analysis.

As described in reference [27] the reliability block diagram (RBD) is used to model the effect of item failures on the system performance. This corresponds often to the physical arrangement of the system components. A block in the diagram represents some basic part of the system for which reliability data are available.

As mentioned before, the system matrix includes all system structure information. From this it is possible to state a RBD or a fault tree. Using additional information about the hardware components it is possible to evaluate the system. The quantification is important for the mentioned optimizing loop. From the system matrix it is possible to develop the minimal cut sets and the minimal paths for the considered system.

The fault tree (FT) quantification is based on the results of the minimal cut set analysis of the system. Therefore the FT generation out of the matrix became possible, if the minimal cut set analysis out of the matrix is feasible. Using the information of the system matrix, the FT can be generated and quantified using a FT evaluation tool. For example the FaultTree+ tool from ISOGRAPH [28] could be used. The result will be an evaluated fault tree.

sec.title: 3.2.2 System matrix
sec.p: The system matrix can be evaluated using the functional block diagram, the information from requirements, the information out of models, and earlier reliability evaluations. This composed system matrix can be used to quantify the reliability and other important quantification parameters of the whole system. If a model (e.g. a MATLAB or UML model) of the system is available, it is possible to generate the FBD out of the model. Furthermore, it is possible to generate the system matrix automatically (see section 3.3.3). Regarding the quantification, reliability information is essential for the automated system matrix development.

For the development of the system matrix the system has to be divided into well known and easy-to-handle subsystems. The input–processing–output chain (Fig. 3) is used to separate the system into the relevant segments. In mechatronic systems micro-controllers are used for the processing of the inputs. Inputs are usually connected with sensors and outputs with actuators. Sometimes the output is a module and is used as input for the following system. This means that a whole system is placed before the considered system and acts as an input.

The system matrix includes all information about the system topology. An overview of a typical system matrix is given in Tables 2 and 3. The system matrix in Table 2 is comprised of six sensors (

Thus parts are described by the functions or modules which need to be integrated into a logical unit (e.g. a micro-controller). The inputs

sec.title: 3.2.3 System matrix development
sec.p:
Using additional information from experts, the system matrix is based upon the functional structure (Fig. 4). The sensors used are (functional) related to the outputs. For example, the result of module 1 (
m
1
) is a
v 1
-link, which represents a 1oo3 VOTER structure. This means that one part of the functional information from the lower layer needs to be fault free to receive output information. In the case of function
f
1
, all inputs are connected by a logical AND. Consequently, all sensors or sensor signals need to be fault free to get a fault-free behaviour of module one. This behaviour is shown in an RBD as a serial structure. The opposite of this structure is the o-link, which represents an OR connection. If the inputs are routed via a logical OR one of the inputs needs to be fault free to receive a fault-free behaviour. This is shown in a reliability block diagram using a parallel connection of the blocks. Other structures are described in detail in reference [29].

sec.title: 3.2.4 Extension of the evaluation possibilities
sec.p:
The system matrix has been further developed. Failure injection, logical integration, power supplies, and system flows can be considered. A flow is represented by an s-labelled link: e.g. a flow of information, flow of material, or flow of energy. Power supply connections are represented by a
p
, whereas the
a
,
o
,
vx
, and
c
denotations are logical denotations. Logical connections put the input information in relation to each other. This is important for reliability calculations of functional structures. All logic components (functions or modules) of the system are integrated, denoted with an
i
, in a logical unit (e.g. micro-controller). The failure injection
e
is useful to simulate common failures. The failure
e
x
was injected and influences all connected nodes.

sec.title: 3.3 Quantification of the qualification values
sec.p: Using the following example, the modelling concept of the system matrix is described based on a modular system structure. This section gives an overview of the calculation strategy of the matrix, methods which are deposited in the matrix background for evaluation of the qualification values. The relations between hardware and the software components are detailed. (This part does not focus on any code guideline checkers or other development guidelines for software components. Software reliability analysis is also not considered. As mentioned before, the focus is related to the functional structure of the system. The greatest part of the functional structure is realized in software. Therefore software only puts the inputs in relation to each other.)

The example (illustrated in Table 2) shows an easy to manage system considering parallel, serial, and voter structures. From this system matrix the system reliability (topology) and the other quantification parameters are automatically evaluated and analysed.

The relation between RBDs and the system matrix is shown in Fig. 6. The following examinations are made under consideration of the Boolean evaluation of system failures. Here the AND alignment is similar to a serial structure in the RBD. In the case of a fault-free system all components need to be fault free. An OR connection is represented by a parallel path. One of the components needs to be fault free to obtain a fault-free system. Due to this, serial structures are more critical than parallel structures.

caption.p: Comparison of the concepts of system matrix and reliability block diagram

sec.p: Initially a system structure analysis is made. Therefore the generated structure includes all information regarding the functional structure of the system. Also, the reliability information has to be filled up to carry out the mentioned reliability calculation. The generated structure is developed as a list as shown in Fig. 7. (The structure illustrated here is implemented inside a control unit and is therefore a software function.)

caption.p:
Reliability block diagram for module 1 (
m
1
)

sec.p: The structure (see Table 4) also contains the information about the signal paths, the reliability, and the quantification parameters of the system. The hierarchical structure of the system is considered. Additionally, the information about the signal junction to the upper and lower layers is given. The generated list is used to describe the structure of the system for the evaluation algorithm. The structure looks like a tree and the output or the objective function is aligned on the top.

The system matrix allows the analysis of the system topology. It is possible to detect the critical path of the system and to evaluate the importance of a component within the investigated functional topology. Therefore, the information and quantification of the signal path is relevant. For the evaluation it is important to note the kind of input value to be used; a multiple use of the input values also needs to be considered.

sec.title: 3.3.1 Analysing and weighting the signal path
sec.p: Quantification of the structural importance of the component is helpful for the optimization process. The quantification of the signal path detects the influence of the component on system reliability. This information is necessary for the detection of weak points regarding critical paths, bottlenecks, etc., of the systems. The structural importance classifies the components within their logical alignment in the system reliability topology, as shown in Fig. 7 [7]. Here the AND connection (serial structure) is more important than an OR connection (parallel structure) [30], because within the serial structure every component has to be fault free. The example graph in Fig. 8 shows the intention of this weighting process. Additionally, the distance to the top event is considered due to the importance calculation. In this analysis the nodes are attached with the importance (RN(i).imp) information. In Table 5 a proposal for the weighting of the links is shown.

The weighting of the signal path depends upon the number of lower-level nodes connected to the focused node. The OR connection is divided by the count of the nodes from the lower level, whereas the AND connection is multiplied by the count of nodes of the lower level. The weighting factors are used for the quantification of the path through the system.

The next step of the system path analysis is focused to the redundancy of the information paths. The system matrix is analysed using the path information. For example, the signal
i
1
(Fig. 13) has two information paths. In this case the information is used by module
m
1
, which is integrated in unit
u
4
. For the resulting paths it is necessary to search all possible combination of paths from
u
4

i
1
. The first path is
u

c

u

. In this case the system is fault tolerant against single failures of

.

sec.title: 3.3.2 Results of the system quantification
sec.p: The result of the analysis of the system structure is comparable to the results when applying the fault tree approach. But difference results from the inverted logic. The fault tree is a top-down method, whereas the RBD development is a bottom-up method. In the evaluation of the RBD, a faulty sensor could lead to a faulty system. A fault tree is developed from the top (system faulty) to the bottom (basic events) [31]. This approach uses the reliability view of the system. This view describes the information which is required in order to receive fault-free output information. The following results of the system matrix quantification (Fig. 8) can be used as templates for further reliability analysis. The structure shown is called a reliability network (RN). The usage and further implementation is described in section 3.5.

The transitions describe the logical relation between the consecutive layers. This information is important for the reliability calculation. If the component is characterized with a reliability value (RN(i).p), it is treated as hardware. These components influence the system reliability and need to be recognized in the system reliability calculation. The resulting reliability network for Table 3 is illustrated in Fig. 13.

sec.title: 3.3.3 Automatic system matrix development
sec.p: As mentioned before, an automated system matrix generation from requirements or architecture description is possible. In such a case, annotation of the requirements or models (architecture) with information for the quantification process is essential.

The process illustrated on the left in Fig. 9 is proposed to analyse models. The model can be described within MATLAB Simulink or another architecture description language. A few approaches deal with the automated analysis of systems and generation of fault trees [13, 14, 16, 32]. The process on the right-hand side in Fig. 9 introduces the analysis of requirements. This proposal is new, in particular the introduction of the annotation of requirements. The result of both processes is the system description within the system matrix. Therefore the structure of the system has to be provided by the models in an appropriate manner. A model parser generates the system structure and requires the reliability information from the system. (In the context of procedural languages an interpreter is used; in the case of description languages a parser (processor) is used to read and analyse the structure and provide the information for further processing.)

If a suitable specification language for the definition of the reliability information is used, an automated generation of the system matrix will become possible. With the use of the programming language PROLOG it is possible to map the system dependencies and the related topology to an internal format. Using the model (system matrix), and the requirements information, an automated system quantification as well as the related analysis becomes possible.

sec.title: 3.4 System failure description (system structure function)
sec.p:
In the following the evaluation of system failures is described in more detail. Using Boolean failure evaluation, each component has two opposite states: fault free or faulty. A ‘0’ denotes faulty and a ‘1’ denotes a fault-free component
C

C

For the first subsystem the system fails if one of the inputs fails. The n-tuple

holds this information. The structure function
Φ (

)
or system function is defined as
This system function is defined for all subsystems and then applied to the whole system function. In the following the serial structure is defined by

The resulting reliability

The evaluation of the Boolean function for easy-handling structures (no component dependencies) is not necessary. In other cases the Boolean function needs to be solved, considering the Shannon decomposition as shown in references [33] and [36]. In the case of larger systems the system structure function is evaluated using minimal cut sets and minimal paths in combination with the separation theorem. The algorithm for evaluating simple system structures is implemented in the system matrix evaluation tool. Implementation of the algorithm to solve complex systems with component dependencies will be addressed in the future. Evaluation of the system fault tree can be performed using the FaultTree+ tool [28].

sec.title: 3.5 Reliability network
sec.p: The reliability networks (RN) are easy-to-handle systems which are described using the system matrix. The modular concept of the matrix allows reuse of the quantified system modules and simplifies the evaluation of the system using easy-to-quantify subsystems.

The variation of the RN is much easier to deal with than changing the whole system matrix. The subsystems represented by the RN are treated as black box systems. Only the functional behaviour and the reliability dependencies of the RN are of interest. The system described in Table 6 and illustrated in Fig. 9 comprises four subnetworks. Each subnetwork was quantified by applying the quantification method described above.

sec.title: 3.6 System construction set
sec.p: The previously-described method builds the core of the system construction set (Fig. 11). The system construction set is used to vary the topology of the system and to generate optimized system structures to be generated automatically from the system descriptions (not part of this contribution, but introduced in reference [4]). The following parts of the system can be optimized by changing the

The variation of system parts requires a modular system design. Each version has to be quantified using the quantification process. After several variation steps it is possible to compare the system easily via a spider chart.

sec.title: 3.7 System quantification and optimization loop
sec.p: The system quantification and optimization loop is shown in Fig. 12. The decision process starts with the quantification of the system.

From this the delta analysis and the sensitivity analysis are derived. The sensitivity analysis is used for the detection of components which are not satisfying the objective. The evaluation of the influence on the system quantification parameters is performed and weak components or bottlenecks in the system structure can be detected. Additional proposals for the optimization process can be made. The delta analysis is used for the comparison of the optimized or changed systems. If the requirements are not fulfilled, the optimization of the structure is induced. This optimization process is described in detail in reference [4]. The result of this process is an optimal system fulfilling all assigned requirements.

sec.title: 4 Summary
sec.p: The proposed approach focuses on the system structure description and quantification. Using the introduced quantification approach the optimization potentials can be detected.

For the quantification of systems a process with three methodological core steps is introduced. The first step focuses to the analysis of requirements in order to produce a preliminary system architecture. The architecture can be described in adequate description languages or models. The next step handles the generation of a suitable system matrix using the architecture of the system and related requirements. With the use of this matrix the quantification process during the product life cycle can be supported. The matrix is detailed more and more during the development of the system. The system matrix is used to describe the system structure in a formal manner and considers additional quantification values (costs, weight, size, etc.). In the case of annotated models or requirements it is possible to automate the system matrix development using parsers. The system matrix considers all values which are necessary for the quantification in the considered context. In this approach the focus is on the quantification of reliability. The last step of the quantification process is the quantification of related system parameters.

To build up the related topology of the system, the subsystems’ structural relationship between sensors, actuators, system hardware (mechanical/electronic), etc., is used. After the topology is created the quantifying process generates the important information. The introduced quantification process is part of the system construction set. The resulting database is helpful for the evaluation of the system. In particular, during the development of innovative products it is helpful to use a database of quantified system component, modules, and topologies. Based on this construction set it is possible to compose a system using modular reliability networks.

The overall product system quantification and optimization loop combines the analysis and quantification of the system. The added part is the optimization of components or structures. One result of the system quantification process is the detection of optimizing potentials and also weakly reliable points of the structure. For this evaluation it is necessary to perform a sensitivity analysis and provide this information to the optimizing process.

The introduced evaluation procedure with respect to system safety and reliability can be used to support design engineers during the whole product life cycle. Subprocesses are introduced to support the engineer in describing the system in a formal manner. As a result of the introduced formalization method, the formal aspect of the calculation of reliability as well as the evaluation of safety aspects is proposed.

sec.title: 5 Outlook
sec.p: The proposed approach considers fault and fault-free states. The generation of the system structure functions is performed, but the method for the evaluation of system reliability of complex systems is not considered. This method can be integrated into the system quantifying process in future. In further steps it will be possible to integrate Markov models to receive a more detailed analysis of system malfunctions. As noted in references [34] to [37], it can also be important to consider the dynamic behaviour for the system matrix.
